snippet: There has been no day of public mourning declared in the Netherlands for the nearly 200 citizens killed aboard Flight 17; nobody is wearing black; flags flying at half-staff are rarely seen.
abstract: Rotterdam Journal; many Dutch citizens are angry over government's response to downing of Malaysia Airlines Flight 17 that claimed the lives of almost 200 of its citizens; Dutch leaders have made no effort to channel country's grief; no day of public mourning has been declared, and flags are rarely seen flying at half-staff.

byline.contributor: Christopher F. Schuetze contributed reporting from The Hague, and Jasper Juinen from Rotterdam.

lead_paragraph: There has been no day of public mourning declared in the Netherlands for the nearly 200 citizens killed aboard Flight 17; nobody is wearing black; flags flying at half-staff are rarely seen.

headline.main: Dutch Grief Abounds, but Mourning Stays Local
headline.print_headline: Dutch Grief Abounds, but Mourning Stays Local
